title: Understanding Type I Error
text: A Type I error occurs when you incorrectly reject a true null hypothesis. This is often referred to as a 'false positive.'

hintAnswer: Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true.
title: Identifying Type I Error
text: Which of the following best describes a Type I error?
choices: Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true.
Failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is false.
Accepting the alternative hypothesis when it is false.
Accepting the null hypothesis when it is true.

title: Understanding Type II Error
text: A Type II error occurs when you fail to reject a false null hypothesis. This is often referred to as a 'false negative.'

hintAnswer: Failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is false.
title: Identifying Type II Error
text: Which of the following best describes a Type II error?
choices: Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is actually true.
Failing to reject the null hypothesis when it is false.
Accepting the alternative hypothesis when it is false.
Accepting the null hypothesis when it is true.

title: Balancing Errors
text: In hypothesis testing, balancing Type I and Type II errors is crucial. Reducing one type of error often increases the other.
